address: Welland Parish Hall, Gloucester Road, Welland, Malvern, Worcestershire WR13 6LA
description: A place to meet up with friends, and also access useful services including Worcestershire Libraries, is located in Welland Village Hall. Serving people in Welland and the surrounding villages including the Hanleys, "Books & a Brew!" is Welland's Social Space and Library. It offers a lovely space to meet up with friends for a coffee, and also to access important services without having to travel to Malvern or Upton. On offer all year round is a "Help yourself" table of free hot & cold drinks & biscuits, free high speed wifi, popular free "Magazine Swap" table, kids colouring activities, lego and board games, and access to most of Worcestershire library's services (you can even return books that you have borrowed from any of the other libraries in Worcestershire). In addition, through the year, there is a programme of special events, including activities and competitions for children, and also valuable opportunities to access useful services right here within the village, such as those provided by Citizen's Advice, Age UK and West Mercia Police. Information about these will be available on the Parish Council website's News page and its Facebook site as well as on posters on the village hall and village notice board next to the shop. All are welcome at Books & a Brew! - you don't have to be a member of Worcestershire Libraries to come along. Dogs on leads also welcome. Open weekly M 2.30-4.30pm, W 8.30-12.30pm, Th 10am-12pm & monthly 10am-12pm on 3rd Sat. Closed Bank Hols & Christmas week. Worcs library services available, also hot & cold drinks, cake/biscuits, kids colouring activities, & free magazine swap table.
title: "Books & a Brew!", Welland's Social Space and Library

description: Welcome to Our Warm Space in Skelmersdale! Located at the heart of Skelmersdale in the Concourse Shopping Centre, our space is a vibrant community hub open to all residents of West Lancashire. We offer a variety of FREE sessions (below) designed to bring people together, offering warmth, connection, food, drink and recreation. Thursday: Cue & Brew Pool Challenge - Adults Only 🕐 1:30 PM - 2:30 PM Come by for a friendly game of pool, whether you’re challenging one of our staff or playing with a friend! Enjoy a complimentary hot drink as part of the experience. Friday: Community Cuppa – Open to All 🕘 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM (including school holidays) Join us for a relaxed morning with free hot and cold drinks, toast, and biscuits. There’s also a selection of arts and crafts activities for anyone feeling creative! Adults Only Games Lounge 🕐 1:00 PM - 2:00 PM Unwind with classic games like dominoes and Scrabble while enjoying free hot drinks and biscuits. It’s a great way to meet new people and have a bit of fun! We also have our 'Community Cupboard' if you are in need some some free essential items such as food and hygiene products - you do not need a referral to access this service.

address: 41 High Street, Hampshire, Hampshire PO12 1DF
description: pop in for a coffee and a chat Everyone needs social connections to survive and thrive. But as people age, they often find themselves spending more time alone. Being alone may leave older adults more vulnerable to loneliness and social isolation, which can affect their health and well-being. Studies show that loneliness and social isolation are associated with higher risks for health problems such as heart disease, depression, and cognitive decline. If you are in poor health, you may be more likely to be socially isolated or lonely. If you are socially isolated or feeling lonely, it can put your physical and mental health at risk. Adults who are lonely or socially isolated are less healthy, have longer hospital stays, are readmitted to the hospital more often, and are more likely to die earlier than those with meaningful and supportive social connections.

address: Cardiff City Stadium, Cardiff (access from Sloper Road), South Glamorgan CF11 8AZ
description: The Warm Welcome project turns Cardiff City Stadium into a warm community hub to address fuel poverty and social isolation. Through weekly sessions, we provide a space for people to come together, share experiences, and find comfort in a supportive group. The weekly Warm Hub sessions are facilitated by our devoted team and volunteers, offering both warmth and comfort. Sessions are free of charge and the first 200 people to attend will receive a complimentary Warm Pack. What's included? Warm Home Packs: Including items such as blankets and hot water bottles, and information to empower individuals to navigate challenges at home. Hot drinks and refreshments will be provided at each session. An opportunity to meet up at Cardiff City Stadium and have a chat. Valuable tips on energy saving with some fun activities! To come along, please register your interest using the link to our website. Where? Disabled Supporters Association room on Level 3 of the Grandstand, Cardiff City Stadium, CF11 8AZ (access from Sloper Road)
title: Cardiff City FCn Warm Welcome Hub

Family hubs can offer free of charge: •Stay and play sessions •Young Carers groups •Connect Café – access to computers and the internet Find your local family hub and view their What’s on Guide’s https://www.wakefieldfamiliestogether.co.uk/family-hubs/

address: Rowsley Village Hall, Matlock, Derbyshire DE4 2EE
description: We run a Community Hub every week on Tuesday mornings (we began in November 2022). We offer a welcoming space for people to meet and have hot drinks and something light to eat. We also provide papers, magazines and puzzles. We provide tea, coffee and cake ‘on a pay as you feel’ donation basis (with free tea and coffee refills). Some people like to pop in for buttered crumpets or teacakes; our ‘bacon butties’ mornings are always popular. We often have themed days, e.g., Pancake Day, where we served fresh pancakes, and also had fun events (including pancake races for children). We also have craft activities (e.g., mosaic making sets), that visitors can come and sit and do, as we have found these mindful activities help people relax, and provide a focus for people who are struggling with anxiety and mental issues. Tables are also set up in the small side room (off the main hall) to provide a ‘quiet space’ for those who find social settings difficult, and this also serves as a ‘shared working from home’ space. Free Wi-Fi is provided. We have incorporated a Parent & Toddler group into the Community Hub, which has been well used and goes from strength to strength. During the holidays we have encouraged the attendance of older siblings and provided craft activities for them to do. We are keen to promote sustainability in the community whenever we can – the GRowsley community group and local allotment holders donate excess produce. Visitors are encouraged to help themselves to these local vegetables, fruit and jam or chutney, or to exchange items e.g., blackberries and apples when in season.
title: Community Hub

Warm spaces are free places where people can relax, have a drink, access free Wifi, meet people and join in activities. The aim is to combat loneliness and improve wellbeing while signposting people to practical help if they need it. Cosy Crafts will have a different craft activity each week that visitors can get involved in, including Indian Block Printing, Card and Gift Bag workshop, Tissue Paper Flower Making and Glass Engraving.

description: Dave's Botanical CoffeeShop is situated in the basement of City Church Liverpool. Access is via a short flight of stairs or a stairlift. Disabled toilets are available. We host a Community Meal on the first Tuesday of most months - which provides a free hot meal and a great opportunity for some social connection to folks in our community. Everyone is welcome. We also run a Friendship Group, which meets monthly on a Wednesday afternoon (weeks vary). This group is predominantly attended by seniors, but everyone is welcome. We have a short time of biblical reflection, a simple craft and there's always a cuppa and something to eat, as well as plenty of time to chat and have fun together! From time to time we hold other events and groups (like our summer Lego Club) that are open to the whole community to come and enjoy. For more details about these Warm Welcome groups, and our special social events please visit our website (linked below).

address: Downside Community Centre, Isle of Wight PO30 2AX
description: Pan Together is an Island charity which exists to support and provide a community hub for the residents of East Newport, which includes the Isle of Wight's most disadvantaged area. Our purpose-built centre comprises: a community cafe providing wholesome, affordable food whilst also acting as a social hub; an IT learning suite; two community rooms; a large training kitchen; and an outside produce-growing area. We provide: vital signposting and support for people needing help and advice; we help to avert social isolation; there are free courses in Maths, English and IT; free weekly drop-in sessions for people wanting to brush up their skills and/or get help with their CV and/or are thinking about returning to work after a break; volunteering and work experience opportunities; social activities such as bingo; cookery sessions for children and vulnerable families; and a new money management advice and form-filling service to support people in these tough economic times. We run a community larder twice a week for local residents. Members pay £5 per weekly visit for two carrier bags of fresh, frozen, refrigerated, tinned and dried food and other household essentials which they choose for themselves. If they pick wisely, they'll receive £20 to £30 of goods and no one needs a referral.
title: Downside Community Centre

address: The Village Hall, Oxfordshire OX29 7UX
description: The Warm Welcome Space at Ducklington Village Hall has been running every Thursday (11.30am – 3pm) since the beginning of November 2022. We offer a friendly, safe, heated space with a free light lunch, cake and hot drinks. We have found that most people enjoy coming for the company and the chat, though puzzle building, knitting and card games are also very popular pursuits. Our volunteers make the refreshments, serve lunch and, most importantly, are a friendly face and love to chat. We are also blessed with donations of wonderful cakes! We are planning more activities in the coming months such as speakers, seated exercise and a film afternoon. The success of Warm Welcome Space in Ducklington is truly down to all our wonderful volunteers, the generous financial donations and the friendly people who come along each Thursday. Please join us if you can either by visiting or becoming a volunteer. All ages are welcome.

address: New Pier Street, Walton on the Naze, Essex CO14 8EB
description: Our Warm Hub initiative commenced on 1 st December 2022 and has taken place almost every Thursday since. The Hub was started in response to the cost of living crisis with people experiencing the effects of increasing energy and household bills. In addition, some people, particularly the elderly, were experiencing social isolation and loneliness following the Covid pandemic. Over the winter months the Hub has offered a warm place for people to meet providing refreshments and homemade soup with a roll at lunchtime, all free of charge. We have continued to provide a space to meet and sandwich/refreshments throughout the summer months too. In addition we provide a free gentle exercise class twice a month between 2.00 and 3.00 p.m. which is funded by Active Essex (dates advertised on the website).

address: Station Road, Filey, North Yorkshire
description: The library is conveniently situated next to the pay-and-display Station Avenue car park, behind the bus station and next door to the surgery. The bus station is served by the number 12, 13 and 555 buses. The nearby train station is only a short walk away. The library has automatic doors and all areas are accessible to wheelchairs. In addition to this, a hearing loop is available. The library also has a disabled toilet for users with a Radar key. Special software and additional hardware, such as keyboards and a lap tray, are available for those with special needs. Information and facilities at the library baby changing, family history, free help and support using IT, home library and information service, induction loop, internet and computer access, magazines and newspapers, parents' collection, photocopying, printing and scanning, study area (limited space) toilets. Activity sessions and storytimes Children's activity sessions are held at the library during school holidays. There is a storytime for under fives every Friday during term-time from 11am to 11.15am. Family history help Family History research available upon request. Filey book group Filey Book group is the last Wednesday of month and U3A is the last Thursday of the month. Information technology taster sessions The library holds information technology taster sessions to introduce people to computers and the internet. Knit and natter group The knit and natter group meets every Thursday from 1pm to 3pm. Sewing Group Our sewing group meets every Wednesday of every month from 2pm to 4pm. Soundings creative writing group The Soundings creative writing group meets on the third Thursday of the month from 10am to 12 noon. Hungry Little Minds Story times Under 5 story time, crafts and songs on Mondays from 10:30am to 11:15am, term-time only.

description: Situated in the heart of Basildon's Eastgate Shopping Centre, HAPPY Hub: Basildon is a bright, spacious space which supports mental health and wellness, and is open to everyone! Not only do we run a multitude of activities devised to support mental health and wellness, but we also sell merchandise specific to supporting and developing mental health through our shop, a community lounge, a safe space to come, sit and relax. You can even pick up a book from our lending library and have a read. Fancy a cuppa, not a problem our CommuniTEA Cafe offers light refreshments, sandwiches and cake. Need to work off the cake, we can help with that too in our physical activity zone, have a game of pool, play table tennis, or use our gym equipment. We also have a learning zone, so watch out for our workshops and short courses. All profits from the cafe, the shop and the sports zone, help support the work we do, as well as the army of volunteers that we have making every thing function like clockwork. The Hub invites the community to use our facilities and to get involved

description: Newly refurbished Harlesden Library is close to the main shopping district in the area, where locals and visitors can enjoy the vibrant and diverse atmosphere, with music emanating from record shops and food from all over the word available in the stores. With special black interest book collections, an exhibition space, adult learning centre, dedicated quiet study booths and a young adult’s area, as well as a new hireable community spacing coming later this year, there’s lots of reasons to stop by. The library is free to use and join, allowing library members to borrow books and use computers. Visitors can access the internet using Wi-Fi, read reference materials, newspapers, magazines, participate in activities, events and more. We also have extensive digital resources available in the library and remotely. Every library has resources for children, young people and adults. Materials not available at a particular library can be requested from a vast network of other London libraries as part of The Libraries Consortium. Please note due to our regular events programme, our libraries can be noisier at some times than others. Please contact the library for more information.

What we are offering: Warm, dry buildings spaces to sit and keep warm Free access to Wi-Fi and free computer access with a Library membership Places to charge your devices Signposting to advice and support Regular groups, activities and events ranging from jigsaw puzzles to social sessions A free warm drink To find out more about what we offer visit gloucestershire.gov.uk/libraries/warm-and-welcome/. description: Whalley Range Community Forum and Manley Park Methodist Church welcome you to our community warm hub on Fridays from 10.00 - 13.00. JNR8 (pronounced generate) is a warm and welcoming space for our community to meet with others, have a cuppa and a crumpet/piece of toast, fruit - and soup and a roll when the weather gets colder! Bring a friend along - or come along on your own and make new friends! We have board games and art materials - or bring your own knitting/craft project along to work on - or you can just sit and read a book. We are a foodbank partner so can help those in food poverty with a foodbank voucher. We often have free bags of essentials such as toiletries and household cleaning products to give away - and a free pre-loved clothes rail to look through. (Also limited SIM cards with free calls and data: ask Chris for details) We invite guests such as Citizens Advice, Scam Awareness, local PCSO's and Councillors - to help with any issues you may have. We can also signpost you to services that might be able to help you if you are struggling. Come and join us at the JNR8 Community Hub for a warm welcome! (the centre is open throughout the week with a range of activities: pop in to check our timetable)

description: During the winter months, Warm Welcome Spaces like ours will open their doors to their local communities, offering everyone a friendly space to keep warm, connect, and make new friends. We here to help, offering you a warm, welcoming, free and safe space in your community. You're Welcome to join our space, it's an open invitation to everyone. Space details: - Wheelchair access to the library with good manoeuvrability - Reference and Local Studies located on the first floor - Lift access to the first floor and to the Lower Ground floor, where the disable toilets are located - Wheelchair access to the Lecture Theatre - No wheelchair access to the Meeting Room behind the lecture Theatre - there are 4 steps and a handrail to access the room For users of the Lecture Theatre and Meeting Room, the disabled toilet is located inside the adjoining GP Surgery. Check out some of our events . ﻿﻿-Bibliotherapy Reading Group (The Reader) - Every Tues, 2pm to 4pm. ﻿﻿-English Conversation Group - Every Fri, 11am to 12pm. ﻿﻿-Age UK Digital Clinic - Every 3rd Thursday of the month, 2pm to 4pm. ﻿﻿-Age Uk Spanish Classes - Every Fri, 2pm to 3pm. ﻿﻿-Reading Group - 3rd Mon of the month, 6.10pm to 7.40pm.

The Lambourn Lunch Club provides a safe, warm place to meet and have a free meal for those who are impacted by the cost of living and rural isolation. We carefully analysed the benefits to the community before starting the Lambourn lunch club and the feedback to date has been very positive indeed. If you would like to join us for a meal and a chat next week, please give Helen a call 07770 394 123 to book a place. description: During the winter months, Warm Welcome Spaces like ours will open their doors to their local communities, offering everyone a friendly space to keep warm, connect, and make new friends. The dark evenings and cold winter months can be challenging for everyone. The winter is especially tough on people who feel lonely and isolated. We here to help, offering you a warm, welcoming, free and safe space in your community. You're Welcome to join our space, it's an open invitation to everyone. Space accessibility: This library is suitable for wheelchairs and can be accessed via the lift on Shirland Road. Alternatively, there are nine steps at the entrance of the library. The library is on one level. Registered assistance dogs are welcome. General Information Facilities and services: - computers - free wifi - study spaces - photocopying, printing and scanning - printer cartridge and battery recycling points plus free recycling bags - rooms for hire Nearest railway station: Marylebone and Paddington stations Nearest tube station: Maida Vale and Warwick Avenue (Bakerloo line), Royal Oak (Circle and Hammersmith & City lines)

description: Malton Library & Information Centre offers a large selection of books, audiobooks, maps, and DVDs that members can borrow. We have free WiFi as well as access to computers which are free for 1hr per day. We run regular activities such as a Stay and Play session for under 5s every Monday at 10.30, and a Storytime every Tuesday at 1030. We also have a Lego Club for families on Wednesdays 13.00-15.00 and Saturdays 10.00-12.00. For the adults we have a craft club on Tuesday evenings from 17.00-19.00 and a board game club on Fridays from 14.00-16.00. All these activities are free and do not require booking. To find out more about library events and activities please check our Facebook page. There are two disabled car parking spaces at the front of the library. Free parking for up to two hours is available in the marketplace, a five-minute walk away, and long and short-stay car parks are about ten minutes' walk away. The library has automatic doors and is accessible to wheelchairs.

address: Westminster City Council, London W1G 9UQ
description: During the winter months, Warm Welcome Spaces like ours will open their doors to their local communities, offering everyone a friendly space to keep warm, connect, and make new friends. The dark evenings and cold winter months can be challenging for everyone. The winter is especially tough on people who feel lonely and isolated. We here to help, offering you a warm, welcoming, free and safe space in your community. You're Welcome to join our space, it's an open invitation to everyone. General Information We a small, friendly community library situated on 2 floors. There are 2 flights of stairs that lead to the basement (16 steps in total), but no passenger lift. Our approachable staff can help if you require assistance. We specialise in services for children: •Under 5's session (Tuesday) •Storytime (Friday) •Craft (Saturday) •Chess Club (Saturday) We also host I.T. sessions for adults: •iTea Parties run by Age UK (Thursday, once or twice a month) •1-2-1 in-house/volunteer led I.T. Training (Monday & Saturday) Our facilities include: •Free Wi-Fi •1 x public desktop PC with Internet access, Microsoft Office, and Supernova software (ground floor) •4 x public laptops with Internet access and Microsoft Office (basement) •Study space (basement) •RADAR toilet (ground floor) Nearest transport links are: •Bond Street Tube Station, Regent’s Park Tube Station, and Baker Street Tube Station. •We are within 15 minutes’ walk from Marble Arch and Oxford Street.

address: Canklow Pavillion, South Yorkshire S60 2JH
description: RotherFed are offering new community-based drop-in session through the Open Arms Community Support Hubs. A range of local voluntary and community groups, including RotherFed, Citizens Advice Rotherham & District, LASER Credit Union, and Voluntary Action Rotherham, have partnered to develop and deliver a co-ordinated response to support communities most affected by the cost of living crisis. RotherFed’s Community Engagement team and advisers will deliver information, advice and guidance at venues across the borough, right in the heart of the community. Residents will be able to access support with a strong focus on financial and social inclusion, empowering communities with a foundation of support, and making better use of community assets. Each hub will have a drop-in session throughout the day every fortnight. The session at Canklow will run on Wednesdays between 9.30am-3.30pm on a fortnightly basis. The project has been made possible by the UK Shared Prosperity Fund, part of the national government’s Levelling Up agenda, which was successfully secured by Rotherham Council and South Yorkshire Mayoral Combined Authority.
title: Open Arms Community Support Hub - Canklow

address: The Park, Newtown, Powys SY16 2NZ SY16 2NZ
description: Croeso Cynnes Warm Welcome Oriel Davies is welcoming visitors to the gallery to experience and enjoy performances, workshops and community events this winter. Croeso Cynnes is a community project with wellbeing at its heart. The project aims to combat personal isolation and address the cost-of-living crisis over the winter months. Activities are free and open to young people, adults and families. Informal performances with Welsh musicians, movement artists and singers will take place on Thursday evening Lates sessions each month and during the day. Mindful workshops for adults are bookable and run over four weekly sessions, supporting wellbeing through movement and crafting. Community days will offer time to connect with others over food, conversation and nature-based creative sessions. For details about upcoming activities go to our website https://orieldavies.org/whats-on Croeso Cynness runs from January to March 2024 and follows a successful programme of activities last winter generously supported by crowd funding and the COOP UK. Croeso Cynnes 2024 is funded by the National Lottery Community Fund
title: Oriel Davies Gallery

address: All Souls - Bolton,, Bolton, England BL1 8EY
description: All Souls is a beautiful historic church that has been converted for use as a conference, office, learning and community space. As part of this work, the original building was carefully restored. Renovation work began in September 2013 and was completed during November 2014. Established by the Greenhalgh brothers in 1881 for the wellbeing of the surrounding community, All Souls will now extend this welcome to a new generation, offering the latest facilities combined with the warm professionalism of our team. All Souls’ place at the heart of the Crompton community makes it the ideal base for local services, activities and events. Its unique beauty makes it a fine place to gain a greater understanding of the heritage of the church and its surroundings. All Souls is open Monday to Friday from 9am till 5pm. Occasionally for events we are open in the evenings and at weekends. All Souls - Bolton is managed by The Churches Conservation Trust, which is a national charity caring for over 350 historic churches in England.

address: Restorative Justice For All International Institute, london, London SE16 2LJ
description: The RJ4All Rotherhithe Community Centre is South East London's hub of community empowerment and cohesion. Through the Centre, we aim to implement our Founder's vision of making SE16 London's first restorative post-code. At RJ4All, we believe that in order to achieve community cohesion and reduce anti-social behaviour, first we must adopt a holistic approach that addresses the reasons that lead to divisions. Poverty and power abuse must be rooted out, if we are genuinely interested in supporting and empowering communities to participate and indeed enjoy civic life equally. To this end, all local service providers (public, private and voluntary) must come together and under the guidance of the restorative justice values of power sharing, equality, dignity and respect support local communities. With the above vision in mind and with the support of our landlord, Clarion Futures Communities , Southwark Council and many local stakeholders, we have set up the following services, which are open to anyone: community fridge, education and digital inclusion, social community space, health and community cohesion, youth club+, wellbeing circle cafe, charity shop and safe house.

description: We started our Public Living Room at Settle Quakers in Autumn 2022 and these run twice a week all year round. We have a selection of games, a local paper and always have a jigsaw on the go. In warmer weather we often take people down to our allotment to help out there or go on short walks. We sometimes do art and craft activities like making soap or beeswax wraps. Hub staff are always available if someone needs a bit of extra help eg with bills, making appointments, benefits or other issues. We have good links with other local organisations, especially Age UK and The Place, so can take people to them for help and advice if need be.

Registered customers will be able to browse the shelves, use the free Wi-Fi, log onto a computer and print from the photocopier, relax and read. The self-services kiosks will be available to return and issue books. You can find out more about Open+ on our website. To register for access, please speak with a member of staff during normal open hours. A short induction is required. The library is open via self service access outside of core library hours. address: 216 High Street, Swansea, Swansea SA1 1PE
description: Swansea MAD is a grassroots, anti-poverty, anti-racist, pro-equality, pro-environmental, inclusive youth and community charity. We work for a fair world in which people can be themselves and thrive! Swansea MAD develops inclusive safe spaces for people to access advocacy, creative arts, education, digital access, employability support, training, campaigning activities and projects to bring fairness and belonging and to influence change for the better. Swansea MAD is part of the Swansea Spaces scheme as a local drop-in Warm Welcome hub, supporting and welcoming people to free food, hot drinks, toiletries, period products, charging points, SIM cards, digital devices and data (and training and support on how to use them). We also provide information and support about energy tariffs and efficiency and support people to register for the Priority Services Register. Swansea MAD also hosts food event every month, where everyone is welcome to share a hot meal and have a chat. Connect with us on our social media platforms to know the dates.

description: Turner Contemporary is an art gallery built on the site of the boarding house where JMW Turner stayed during his visits to Margate, the gallery is inspired by the life and work of the celebrated artist, who found inspiration in the town’s skies and light and believed in the power of art as an agent for change. Visitors to Turner Contemporary can enjoy the latest art exhibition, take part in tours or activities, or use the learning space to relax and access the children's art library. The gallery also has a cafe, shop and toilets. Staff are on hand to welcome you, chat or help you engage with any of our offers. The gallery is free to access all year. Over the winter the gallery is open Wednesday to Sunday 10am until 5pm and you are welcome to stay as long as you want.

description: The Renewal Programme have launched their Stay Warm in Newham project and have opened their first warm bank on Tuesday 24th January 2023. Newham residents are encouraged to attend our warm bank sessions to access energy- related advice/services and activities, to help reduce energy cost. We also provide a welcoming space for residents to enjoy tea and coffee with some company. Our warm bank runs three days a week on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays at The Renewal Programme. You will have the opportunity to engage with our energy experts, Groundwork’s Green Doctors, who will be there every Tuesday to offer advice to residents on how to reduce energy cost while keeping their home warm. They also provide in-depth referrals via telephone calls or home visits (subject to eligibility). We are also providing hot meals every Wednesdays from 12:00pm- 1:00pm. We have a wide range of halal and vegetarian options. Everyone is welcome from Newham!
title: Warm Bank

address: Royston Museum, Royston, Hertfordshire SG8 5AL
description: SPACE OPENING ON 16th February 2024** Royston Museum's new Community Room will be open as a warm space from Friday 16 February. Everyone in our community is welcome to use our new warm space: adults, families and those in need. There will be tables and power points available for those needing space to work, a small selection of board games for those wishing to socialise plus additional activities and facilities for families. Free tea and coffee will be available. The warm space will be available during the Museum's normal opening hours: Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 10am to 4pm. The Community Room will be unavailable on a small number of dates due to private bookings, however the rest of the Museum will be open to enjoy. Royston Museum is located near the centre of Royston, it is easily accessible by road, rail and public transport. The Museum is accessible via a ramp at the main entrance. The downstairs consists of the Exhibition Hall and a new accessible toilet with baby changing facilities. The Community Room is upstairs, so unfortunately is not accessible to all. Our team will be happy to help you find an alternate space downstairs in the Museum. Please email us at hello@roystonmuseum.org.uk if you have any questions before visiting.

A new functional fitness area is the perfect place for a HIIT work out and two further studios host a wide variety of Fitness Classes for all ages and abilities. This includes a multi purpose black out studio for interactive group cycle and yoga classes. The centre has a 25m fitness pool and a leisure pool with slides and a wave machine, sauna and Jacuzzi making it the perfect place for all your water activities including our Better Swim School lessons, aqua aerobics, fitness swims and family sessions. Facilities available for hire include a multi-use sports hall, indoor 5-a-side pitch and squash courts. Waterfront Leisure Centre is conveniently located, only a short walk from Woolwich DLR Station and the new Elizabeth Line Tube Station. description: West Lakes Hemp Coffeeshop: A Neurodiversity Hub and Community Space Nestled in the heart of Cumbria, West Lakes Hemp Company offers more than just a cup of coffee. It's a vibrant community space where warmth and laughter are brewed alongside our unique CBD-infused beverages. Our Coffeeshop, renowned for its cozy, welcoming atmosphere, is a popular gathering spot for locals and visitors alike. We're proud to be more than just a coffee shop. As an active participant in community welfare, we run several projects reflecting our commitment to social responsibility: **Women's Period Poverty Collection Point:** - We believe in supporting those in need. Our collection point for menstrual products helps address period poverty in our community, ensuring everyone has access to essential hygiene products. **Suspended Coffee Scheme:** Inspired by the tradition of "caffe sospeso," we embrace the spirit of paying it forward. Customers can purchase an extra coffee, which we 'suspend' for someone in need – a simple gesture that warms hearts and uplifts spirits. **ADHD Cumbria Hub:** Understanding the unique challenges faced by individuals with ADHD, our coffee shop doubles as a hub for ADHD Cumbria. Here, we provide a supportive space for sharing experiences, accessing resources, and building a supportive community. At West Lakes Hemp Company, we're more than a business; we're a part of the community fabric, dedicated to making a positive impact. Join us for a coffee and be part of our mission to make the world a little brighter & a little greener, one leaf at a time.

address: City Of Westminster, London, London SW1P 2DE
description: During the winter months, Warm Welcome Spaces like ours will open their doors to their local communities, offering everyone a friendly space to keep warm, connect, and make new friends. The dark evenings and cold winter months can be challenging for everyone. The winter is especially tough on people who feel lonely and isolated. We here to help, offering you a warm, welcoming, free and safe space in your community. You're Welcome to join our space, it's an open invitation to everyone. This library can be accessed by wheelchair. There is level access from the pavement into the ground floor café and Westminster Adult Education Service area. There is also a wheelchair-accessible lift down to the library level as well as 2 wheelchair accessible toilets. The library can also be accessed by a 21-step staircase. Registered assistance dogs are welcome. Accessibility Features Wheelchair Accessible Lift Accessible Toilet Assistance Dog Amenities (Water, others) Accessible Rooms No specific assistance needed
title: Westminster Archives

address: City Of Westminster, London WC2H 7HP
description: During the winter months, Warm Welcome Spaces like ours will open their doors to their local communities, offering everyone a friendly space to keep warm, connect, and make new friends. The dark evenings and cold winter months can be challenging for everyone. The winter is especially tough on people who feel lonely and isolated. We here to help, offering you a warm, welcoming, free and safe space in your community. Space accessibility: There is no wheelchair access but we can make our material available at another Westminster library branch upon request. There are two steps at the entrance, then six steps immediately inside the building to the ground floor. The library is on three floors with stairs to all levels but there is no lift. You can find the following collections on each floor: - ground floor: performing arts, fine art, design and photography collections - first floor: Westminster Music Library - second floor: a quiet reading and study area and a collection of art books for loan. Registered assistance dogs are welcome. This is a specialist public reference library with regular and varied events, exhibition space and a business information point. There are also three reading rooms available for reading and study. Facilities and services: - Computers - book a PC - Free wi-fi - Hublet - borrow a Samsung tablet to use in the library with your - - Westminster library card - photocopying, printing and scanning - study area

address: Yate Heritage Centre, Bristol, Avon BS37 5BG
description: Yate & District Heritage Centre is a fully accredited museum which, as part of Yate Town Council, serves all our local communities. The Centre was created in 1995 to provide facilities for displaying aspects of Yate’s past history and for providing archive and research facilities for the storage of artefacts, documents, maps and photographs relevant to Yate. In 2000, the Centre was relocated to a new venue next to St Mary’s Church; the site of former stables dating from the 1840’s, behind the historic White Lion Pub. Yate Town Council funded and supported the creation of the purpose-built exhibition galleries and a workroom which houses the archive and also provides storage space.

address: 152 YG Hub, Gloucestershire GL205JP
description: SPACE OPENING ON 28th November 2023** Our door is open to all young people to enjoy our warm and well space. You will be welcomed by our lovely youth workers when you arrive and be offered to make food and grab a drink. Our cooking appliances include a microwave, toaster, airfyer and a toasty maker. Our youth workers will be on hand to help you cook if you need and any dietary requirements can be met upon request. The hub has a common area with sofas and bean bags on the first floor and multiple rooms upstairs set up with comfy chairs and a table. On the top floor is a chill out room with a tv, books and various games and activities. We want you to use this space as your own, so feel free to come and hang out with friends, play games, study or chill out and eat. If you have any concerns our youth workers will be happy to listen and support you in any way they can. We are open every Tuesday and Thursday from 4-6pm from the 28th November 2023 - 8th February 2024. We look forward to seeing you there!

description: Our Community Hub at the Parish Hall be will open every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday morning 10am –12pm where we will be serving light refreshments including tea, coffee, cakes, biscuits. There will be no charge for entry or refreshments, and we have a team of volunteers hosting the sessions. Every Tuesday afternoon you are welcome to join in on our free gentle fitness class 12.30pm – 1.30pm run by Lets Dance Sussex. We will also be hosting a week of Christmas activities including a family friendly film over the Christmas holiday plus much more from January, so do keep an eye on our Facebook page for more details. Everyone is welcome!

Based at Wilton Road United Reformed Church, the organisation provides a range of activities across the week including arts and crafts activities for young people with learning disabilities (in partnership with ATHAC CIC), IT and English Classes (with Birmingham Adult Education Service), a Seniors group and Women’s group, and a Job Club (in partnership with New Beginnings Creative CIC).  The organisation is also part of B-CAN – Energy – a collaboration between five organisations in North Birmingham providing advice and support to households on energy saving measures and reducing utility bills, and also FLOURISH – a collaborative of organisations in West Birmingham working to improve health and wellbeing.

title: Lads and Dads

address: Emmaus Shop, Caroline Street, Bridgend, CF31 1DQ
description: The Emmaus South Wales Library of Things is a new low-cost borrowing initiative which aims to help people borrow useful items they may only need for a few jobs or short amount of time. Instead of buying a new item that ends up never being used again, members can pay a small fee to borrow it, use it and return it when they’re done with it! The scheme, which is based at our Bridgend shop on Caroline Street, allows for low-cost borrowing which helps our members from all walks of life, allows people to use stuff that they don’t have space to store around their home, and promotes the idea of an environmentally-friendly circular economy where the same items get used multiple times instead of just once. All our items are priced at a recommended borrowing amount which we believe to be fair and accessible to most households. If you are feeling the squeeze on your living costs, do not hesitate to come in and we can sort out an adjusted price for you. We will work with you to make sure the price is as fair as possible. Photo I.D. and proof of address will be required for the first time you borrow. Facebook : @EmmausSWales Website: emmaus.org.uk 01656 750829 Opening Hours: Mon – Saturday, 9.30am - 4.30pm

A warm, welcoming hub of activity, free courses and social events. We have a cafe, winter warming clothing and school uniform shop, community grocery and food parcels. Paid on scheme available should emergency food be needed
Burnley Together staff will be able to help you and signpost to specialist agencies. Monday am - advocacy support Tuesday am employment advice Tuesday am - whole family support Wednesday am - citizens advice Also support with health, housing, volunteering, employment, energy advice and food
BUS: Burnley bus station is a 5 minute walk away
CHARGES: Suggested small monetary donation in the Relove the Preloved shop with school uniform and winter warmers Energency food parcels. Reduced shop in the community grocery. In all cases, if individuals are struggling to pay please speak to a member of the Burnley Together team

description:
Our lounge is based in the Gallery in Emmanuel Centre.

Open every Friday 10am-4pm

Light refreshments all day, light lunch of soup and roll, (Rolls, wraps, fillings in the summer months).

 Time to chat, read a newspaper, just sit, do a puzzle, weekly craft activities, meet new people or be on your own in a quiet reflective space to be still or pray. 

A very friendly space where everyone is welcome, regardless of age. 

Pop in for a quick drink/chat or come and stay as long as you wish

title: Resurrected Bites @ St Paul's United URC

hours._text: We are open Monday mornings - 10.30-12.00 1st & 3rd Mondays is our Sewcial group - Anyone is welcome, people bring knitting, crochet etc but also some make cards, some do jigsaws, some play table tennis, and other table games and others just drink coffee and chat. Men and Women attend. 2nd & 4th Mondays - we have a fellowship group that have speakers come, some weeks there might be a beetle drive and occasionally they have lunch together. No group meets on the 5th Monday. Tuesday mornings there is a group meets between 10-12 they sing worship songs together and discuss biblical or ethical ideas. People would be welcome to come in and have a coffee even if they didn't want to join in with the group, there is space where they could come in and either have quiet time or read or chat with a friend. They only meet in term time. Wednesday our church is open for bible study from 10.00 to 11.45am much like Tuesday people would be welcome to come in, join in or find a space just to be warm.

Hot Breakfast 8.20-8.45am Monday - Saturday Hot Meal 4.30-4.50pm Monday, Wednesday, Friday (takeaway option available) Mini Super Market 4.30-4.50pm Thursdays - (an opportunity to stock up on tins and bread) Sunday Lunch 1.00-1.30pm Sundays Meals and mini supermarket produce are provided for those in need on a no questions asked basis.

description: Luton Libraries are open to the public to join and make use of our building resources. This includes books, PC’s, photocopying and more. We also host regular activities across all our branches for all ages and abilities to join in with. Please note that warm drinks/refreshments are not provided by libraries. Members of the public are welcome to bring in their own tea/coffee flasks etc. from elsewhere though. Libraries are open to all during opening hours. Certain activities are age restricted, please speak to a team member for more information. Full details can be found on our website: https://www.lutonlibraries.co.uk/home
title: Luton Central Library

address: LU2 0QN
description:
Welcome Space Warm food and activities. The venue offers a warm welcome and a place to relax and meet others. This service is open to all but it runs in term time only. While there is a charge for some of the Thursday food service provisions listed below, nobody will go home unfed. The food related provision is as follows: 2nd Thursday of the month - Bacon Butty Morning from 10am to 12 noon for which there is a charge of £2.50 per session. 3rd Thursday of the month - Hart Lane Community Lunch, beginning at 12 noon for which there is a charge of £2.50 per session. 4th Thursday of the month - Community Refreshment Stop from 10am to 12 noon and donations are welcomed. Each of these provides opportunities to gather and for friendships to be renewed, made or continued. St Anne's also runs 2 Craft Groups although there is no food at these other than tea and biscuits. They run:
1 - A weekly Craft Group on Tuesdays from 10am - 12 noon in term time only, and 2 - A weekly Scrapbooking and Crafts on Saturdays from 10am until mid afternoon, but please note that this group does not run during the month of August.
title: St Anne's Church

title: Talking Cafe for community connections in OX4

description: @Flo's - The Place in the Park. Pay-As-You-Can on Mondays From 12-2pm on Mondays our normal menu is suspended and instead we will be serving a delicious hot lunch, sweet treat and hot and cold drinks on a “pay what you can basis”. There is no judgement and how much you pay is anonymous- everyone is welcome! The café is open the rest of the time from 10am until 4pm serving delicious brunch, hot lunch specials, sandwiches, salads, and sweets, expertly roasted coffee. All the money spent at the café feeds into the local economy and funds our community activities at Flo’s. Pay-as-you-can Mondays are part of the OX4 Food Crew- a partnership of local organisations working to tackle food inequality in OX4.

address: Alma Street, Sheffield, S3 8RY
description: Kelham Island Museum celebrates 300 years of Sheffield making history Explore the story of making in the city, from master craftsmen to mass production. Experience life and work during the Industrial Revolution, follow the sights and sounds of progress through the Victorian era, celebrate the Women of Steel and see how industry forged the modern city. Youâ€™ll hear the roar and feel the rumble of the mighty River Don Engine, the 425 ton 12,000hp visitor-favourite in steam twice a day Thursday-Sunday, and find out more about the industry that saw Sheffield become world-renowned for making and innovation. During your visit you'll have a chance to: - See the pioneering Sheffield Simplex cars and more in the Transport Galleries - Step back in time as you stroll along the cobbles of Little Mesters Street - Explore the Hawley Tool Collection, chronicling centuries of skilled craftsmanship and precision manufacturing - See the Crossley Gas Engine and Die-Sinkers Workshop in action - Find out about life on the home front in Sheffield in the 1916 House There's also a cafe on site.
title: Kelham Island Museum

description: The Millennium Gallery brings the best in art and design to Sheffield The gallery's changing exhibition programme showcases the best in national and international art and design alongside the region's remarkable creative talents. You'll also find collection displays celebrating Sheffield's metalworking prowess and the remarkable art and artefacts brought to the city by the artist and writer, John Ruskin. Sheffield's Metalwork Collection is one of the finest in the world. You'll see over 800 examples of the cutlery, flatware and tableware that have made the city famous, as well as beautiful objects collected from every continent. The gallery is also home to the Guild of St George's unique Ruskin Collection. Spanning art, illustrated manuscripts and minerals, the collection was established in the 1800s to inspire the people of Sheffield. Today, it's showcased through regularly changing displays celebrating the contemporary relevance of Ruskin's visionary ideas. There's also a cafe, Ambulo, on site which is open Tuesday-Sunday.

address: Western Bank Sheffield S10 2TP
description: Weston Park Museum tells the stories of Sheffield and its people, from pre-history to present day. You can enjoy a warm welcome and explore free exhibitions and displays, alongside a programme of talks, tours and events. Originally opened in 1875, Weston Park Museum has found lifelong fans in younger visitors and grown-ups alike for nearly 150 years. You'll discover everything from archaeological treasures to zoological wonders, meet visitor favourites Spike the Woolly Rhino and Snowy the Polar Bear, and find out more about the people and events that shaped the city we know today. It's also home to a programme of changing exhibitions and events for all ages. In the Picturing Sheffield gallery, you'll see Sheffield-themed highlights from the city's art collection, including work by Pete McKee, Jo Peel, Stanley Royle, Joe Scarborough, and Emilie Taylor, as well as John Singer Sargent's much-loved The Misses Vickers. You can explore life in Ancient Egypt and unearth amazing artefacts spanning centuries in the Beneath Your Feet gallery. Over in What On Earth, you'll find out more about the city's changing wildlife and environment. In Sheffield Stories and Sheffield Life & Times, you'll discover the people and events that shaped the city and how life in Sheffield has changed over the years. There's also a cafe, Ambulo, on site which is open Tuesday-Sunday.
title: Weston Park Museum

description: Theatre Royal Bury St Edmunds is opening its Greene Room bar around some of our pantomime performance days for those who would like to make use of the space. Free tea and coffee, with bar snacks and other drinks available to purchase, free WiFi and a warm, welcoming safe space in a working theatre. Come along to work, to chat or just to enjoy a hot drink with a friend. Everyone is welcome.

description: Our warm space at The Royal Oak is open for anyone to come and sit, relax and get cosy throughout the winter months. Kick back on our sofas or bring your laptop and work in our cafe, without worrying about the bills. Bring your little ones along with lots of toys and games to keep them entertained!
title: Royal Oak - Emmaus Suffolk

address: 28 Wingfield Street, Bungay NR35 1EZ, UK
description: Warm Welcomes is a warm welcoming safe space for everyone run by Bungay Community Support. We invite you to meet with others, have free refreshments and join in with friendly company. There are books, board games and other activities to enjoy. we can provide information on other support if needed.
title: Warm Welcomes at Number 28

address: Haverhill Arts Centre, High Street, Haverhill CB9 8AR, UK
description: Keep warm this winter! Thanks to funding from West Suffolk council, we are hosting a series of FREE craft Saturdays throughout January and February to make some unique artwork with everyday items. Each workshop will run from 11:00am – 2:30pm. Visitors will also receive a free hot drink and biscuits. No need to book, just drop in! Saturday 20 January – create monster peg pets, with the Crafty Foxes Join the crafty foxes and make some cute monster peg pets with pens, wool, paint and googly eyes. Saturday 27 January – dandylion art, with the Crafty Foxes The crafty foxes will help you create your own dandylion artwork on black sugar paper using white paint and cardboard tubes. Saturday 3 February – details TBC, with the Fabric Seagull Saturday 10 February – details TBC, with the Fabric Seagull Saturday 17 February – shrinky dink keyrings, with the Crafty Foxes Wanted to make your own keyrings using special shrinking paper? Freestyle your own design or use crafty foxes templates to make funky key chains. Saturday 24 February – crazy labyrinth puzzles, with the Crafty Foxes Recycle old CD cases to make your own 3D labyrinth maze puzzle.
title: Winter Warmers -Free Craft Workshops

description: The Southam Warm Space offers friendship, support and advice to everyone looking for a place to meet in Southam. Held every Wednesday from 11am to 4pm we offer hot drinks, food, free wi-fi, newspapers and much more. There is no charge to attend and we have people stay for 15 minutes and we have people stay for 3 hours. Come and join us. There’s always a warm welcome.
title: Southam Warm Space

address: Hurley Village Hall, Knowle Hill, Hurley, CV9 2JD
description: A warm welcome with hot beverages provided free of charge (donations are welcome). Open to all ages and dogs. We will be also offering some free exercise classes, quizzes, bingo through the autumn and winter. Citizens Advice are visiting on 1st October to offer advice and support to pensioners whom may be able to apply for Pensioners Credit.
title: Hurley Community Hub

address: 23 Albert Street Rugby, CV21 2SD
description: Everything is free in our Warm hub, we serve tea/coffee and biscuits everyday, and Hot meals every Friday. We are a safe space to make friends and have a chat, and we are located right in the centre of Rugby.
title: Harvest Fellowship Warm Hub

address: Unit 40-41 Rugby Central Market Mall, Rugby CV21 2JR
description: Everything is free in our Warm hub, we serve tea/coffee and biscuits everyday, and Hot meals every Friday. We are a safe space to make friends and have a chat, and we are located right in the centre of Rugby.
title: Harvest Fellowship Warm Hub

address: Saints Nuneaton, Newdegate Street, CV114ED
description: During our opening hours, anyone is welcome to come in and warm up, there is no pressure to purchase anything from our coffee shop. We have board games and lego, as well as a mini library of books to read! We also operate a pay it forward scheme, meaning every day there is a selection of meals and hot drinks available to be claimed for free by anyone in need. We have a range of free and low cost community activities happening during the week, check out our website for the most up to date events programme!
title: Saints Nuneaton Central

address: Alcester Methodist Church Priory Rd Alcester B49 5DX
description:
This is a free event (although we do accept donations) open to anyone in the community to chat, do crafts, play games and get to know one another. In November we extend our opening hours once a month (possibly more) for a Lunch Club, where we have soup, roll and cake.
We can have up to 35 people in the morning and up to 12 staying for lunch – we hope to increase that this year.

hours._text: Every Tuesday, 10.00am - 12.00 noon all year round, and 10.00am - 2.00pm from November to March

address: Ambleside Care Home, Evesham Road, Stratford upon Avon, CV37 9TG
description:
Free Entry, Free Parking,

10.00 – 12.00 noon: Dementia Friendly Community Café. A chance to make new friends over a tea or coffee with other refreshments provided. A chance to meet people who are in a similar circumstance and make those vital connections out in the community.

2.30 – 4.30pm: Knit and Natter. Those that attend the knit and natter group knit blankets and donate them to worthy causes. This is free to attend and coffee and refreshments are provided. It’s a chance to feel part of something and make new friends along the way.
title: Ambleside Care Home

Everyone is welcome.
title: Westbury Community Centre

address: Southam Youth Club, Graham Adams Centre, Southam, CV47 0LY
description:
Run by our youth worker and volunteers, we offer a FREE family drop in after school. Come and take part in activities, use our wifi and get the information/advice you need. Free refreshments are available.

We will have toys and crafts for the children to play with and access to our multi-play table (air hockey, pool, table tennis) and table football. Parents will be provided with information and advice and children can be helped with their homework.
title: Graham Adams Centre, Southam Family Space

address: Cottage Square, Leamington Spa CV31 1PT
description:
The Warm and Well Hub is run to support people with cost of living issues and to offer a regular, inclusive and welcoming social outlet for anyone feeling lonely or isolated in the community.

Free lunch and cost of living advice. Games for anyone not wanting to engage in the cost of living activity including short mat bowls, table tennis and board games. Guest speakers and activities.

Call 01926 422071 or email wellbeing@sydni.org to register (20 spaces weekly)
